trl.verification_notes: Corrected from TRL 8 to TRL 9. NDL successfully demonstrated on Intuitive Machines IM-1 lunar landing mission (Feb 22, 2024), providing accurate measurements within 5m and 0.5 m/s per NASA technical report. This represents successful flight proven mission operations.
trl.notes: Flight proven on IM-1 lunar landing (Feb 2024), flight tested on NASA F-18, Masten Xodiac, helicopter tests

performance_specs.value: Velocity accuracy: within a few cm/sec, distance accuracy: within a few feet, frequency modulated continuous wave method provides simultaneous range and velocity measurement, modular software-defined capability
performance_specs.verification_notes: Updated performance specs based on NASA official source. NASA states 'within a few centimeters per second' for velocity and 'within a few feet' for distance. IM-1 mission achieved within 5m and 0.5 m/s accuracy per NASA technical report.

heritage.value: Intuitive Machines IM-1 lunar landing (Feb 22, 2024), NASA F-18 flight tests, Masten Xodiac suborbital tests (COBALT 2017), helicopter flight tests, selected for Astrobotic Griffin Mission
heritage.verification_notes: Updated heritage to include successful IM-1 lunar landing mission and various flight tests per NASA sources. IM-1 mission represents first successful lunar landing demonstration.

items.notes: Commercial Navigation Doppler Lidar for precision landing, NASA Phase III SBIR for photonic integrated circuit integration, significantly more precise than radar with reduced SWaP

trl.verification_notes: Corrected from TRL 6 to TRL 7. CAPS successfully demonstrated in operational cislunar environment on CAPSTONE mission with five successful crosslink measurements with LRO (first on May 9, 2023). Mission has been operating 670+ days at the Moon, demonstrating autonomous positioning capability. This represents TRL 7: working prototype demonstrated in operational environment.
trl.notes: NASA SBIR Phase 2 aimed for TRL 4→6, exceeded with successful on-orbit demonstrations

performance_specs.value: Peer-to-peer navigation using relative tracking between vehicles, enables autonomous absolute navigation, reduces ground-based tracking requirements. Demonstrated crosslink measurements computing range and trajectory between spacecraft.

items.notes: Peer-to-peer cislunar navigation technology, demonstrated on CAPSTONE, future applications for lunar surface and orbit navigation

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 7: Successfully tested on Intuitive Machines IM-1 mission lunar surface (Feb 22, 2024). Represents working prototype demonstrated in operational environment.
